questions.question: I once studied classical music …………… about two years.
questions.description: Use for with a period of time.

questions.question: I am going to Switzerland ………….. the summer.
questions.description: Use for with a period of time.

questions.question: I will be in Singapore ……………. the next ten days.
questions.description: Use for with a period of time.

questions.question: We have known each other …………… our school days.
questions.description: Use since with the starting point.

questions.question: We have known each other …………… a long time.
It was the worst disaster ………….. decades.
questions.description: We can use in to talk about duration. This is particularly common after negatives and superlatives. For is also possible here.

questions.question: She has been a go-getter …………… her earliest childhood.
questions.description: With perfect tenses, since and for are more common.

questions.question: …………….. now on, I am going to be punctual.
questions.description: We use from with the starting point. The difference between from and since is that since is mainly used with perfect tenses.

questions.question: I work ……………… dawn to dusk.
questions.description: We use from with the starting point. It is mainly used with simple tenses.

questions.question: …………….. his earliest childhood, he hated cats.
I will be home …………. Monday on.
……………….. the dawn of civilization, people have made wars.
questions.description: We can use 'from' in expressions that mean right from the start.
